sub_topic: Finding the chromatic polynomial of a graph.
message_1: Consider a simple graph G with 5 vertices and 6 edges such that each vertex has a degree of 3. Find the chromatic polynomial of G.
message_2:
A simple graph G with 5 vertices and each vertex having a degree of 3 implies that G is a complete graph with 5 vertices, denoted as K5. The chromatic polynomial of a graph counts the number of proper colorings of the graph using at most k colors.

The chromatic polynomial P(G, k) of a complete graph K_n is given by the formula:

P(K_n, k) = k(k - 1)(k - 2)...(k - n + 1)

For K5, n = 5, so the chromatic polynomial P(K5, k) is:

P(K5, k) = k(k - 1)(k - 2)(k - 3)(k - 4)

This is the chromatic polynomial of the given graph G.
